column1: From 1795 to 1822 the city changed hands several times along with the colony it headed. It was ceded to France in 1795 after years of struggles. However
column2: the French failed to consolidate this cession
column3: mainly because of the continued presence of British troops in Saint-Domingue (they remained until 1798). As the news of Santo Domingo's cession became known on the island
column4: many Dominicans had sided with Britain against France
column5: welcoming British ships into their ports
column6: pledging allegiance to the British in exchange for protection
column7: and enlisting in the military forces of France's nemesis. The city was briefly captured by Haitian rebels in 1801
column9: and was once again reclaimed by Spain in 1809. In 1821 Santo Domingo became the capital of an independent nation called the Republic of Spanish Haiti after the Criollo bourgeois within the country
column10: led by José Núñez de Cáceres
column11: overthrew the Spanish crown. The nation was conquered by Haiti just two months later. The city and the colony lost much of their Spanish-born peninsular population as a result of these events which caused a great deal of instability and unrest.On 27 February 1844 Santo Domingo was again the capital of a free nation
column12: when it gained its independence from Haiti

column18: are a few of the most prominent encounters

column20: and he failed (in 1846) to convince France to establish a protectorate in the Dominican Republic. Báez went on to serve as President from 1849 to 1853 and from 1856 to 1858
column21: and he launched a naval offensive against Haiti. The Dominican Navy attacked Haitian ports and ships in southern Haiti
column22: effectively destroying the Haitian Navy. In 1861 Spain returned to the country

column1: Over the next two-thirds of a century Santo Domingo and the Dominican Republic went through many revolutions and power changes. Santo Domingo would experience the first of two U.S. invasions in 1916 when different leaders fought for presidential power and control of the city. The United States intervened
column2: instituting a military leader
column3: Harry Shepard Knapp. U.S. Marines and Dominicans clashed in Santo Domingo on October 24–25
column5: resulting in the deaths of two U.S. Marines and three Dominicans. Eventually the Americans withdrew in 1924.The city was struck by hurricane San Zenón in 1930
column6: which caused major damage. After its rebuilding
column7: Santo Domingo was known officially as Ciudad Trujillo in honor of mulatto dictator Rafael Leónidas Trujillo
column8: who governed from 1930. Trujillo imposed a cult of personality and on 2–8 October 1937 he ordered a massacre against Haitians in the Dominican Republic in the "Parsley Massacre"
column10: 000 people. Following his assassination in 1961 the city was renamed back to Santo Domingo.

column2: Juan Bosch was elected to the presidency. He was overthrown seven months later

column1: Amid the clatter of automatic weapons

column3: the paratroopers of the 82nd U.S. Airborne Division blasted their way four city blocks into Caamaño's bastion. Heavy fire from U.S. guns across the Ozama River ringed rebel headquarters on El Conde Street
column4: shattered buildings and started huge fires.

column1: The Ozama river flows 148 kilometres (92 miles) before emptying into the Caribbean Sea. Santo Domingo's position on its banks was of great importance to the city's economic development and the growth of trade during colonial times. The Ozama River is where the country's busiest port is located.
The average temperature in Santo Domingo varies little
column2: because the tropical trade winds help mitigate the heat and humidity throughout the year. Thanks to these trade winds
column3: Santo Domingo has a tropical climate but seldom experiences the heat that one may expect to find. December through March are the coolest months with hot days with less humidity and fresh nights (temperatures of 17 to 19 °C (63 to 66 °F)). July through September are the warmest. Santo Domingo averages 1
column4: 445 millimetres (56.9 in) of rain annually. Its driest months are from December through April
column5: however
column6: due to the trade winds and mountains to the southwest
column7: rain is seen even during these months. Because its driest month is just below 60 millimetres (2.4 in)
column8: Santo Domingo falls under the tropical monsoon climate category under the Köppen climate classification. Like many other cities in the Caribbean
column9: Santo Domingo is very susceptible to hurricanes. Hurricane Georges caused severe destruction in September 1998. The lowest recorded temperature has been 11.0 °C (51.8 °F) on 5 February 1951 and 7 January 1957 and the highest is 39.5 °C (103.1 °F) on 29 May 2002.

The city proper of Santo Domingo is subdivided into incorporated areas (neighbourhoods) called sectores which could be considered as small urban towns. All sectores are serviced directly by the municipal mayor's office.

column1: The demographics of Santo Domingo are similar to other metropolitan areas of the country
column2: except that the population of immigrants (mainly Haitians) is larger in the city because of the relative ease of finding work and the economic dynamism compared to other provinces. Santo Domingo
column3: like most of the country
column4: is made up of native-born Dominican mulattos
column5: though there are large numbers of Afro-Dominicans and Euro-Dominicans
column6: as well as a large immigrant community. In fact
column7: over 20% of the city's population is composed of immigrants
column9: there are also recent immigrants from Europe
column11: as well as other Latin American nations present in the city. The city of Santo Domingo has a significant community of Asians (mainly Chinese)
column13: and Europeans (mostly Spanish and Italian people) are also present in the city. There are also significant numbers of Venezuelans and Puerto Ricans
column15: as well as U.S.-born Dominicans returning to their parents' home country. The northeast quadrant of the city is the poorest while the southwest is wealthier. Santo Domingo is also considered one of the epicenters of the growing Dominican middle-class. The city is one of the most economically developed cities in Latin America. Santo Domingo's population in 2010 was 3.8 million in the metropolitan area.

The city is the center of economic activity in the Dominican Republic. It is where most of the country's wealth is concentrated and the seat of the national legislature
column2: judicial
column3: and executive government. Many national and international firms have their headquarters or regional offices in Santo Domingo. The city attracts many international firms and franchises such as Ikea

column1: The infrastructure is suitable for most business operations. A key element that has helped the city grow and compete globally is the telecommunications infrastructure. Santo Domingo and the Dominican Republic as a whole enjoy a modern and extensive telecommunications system liberalized in the late 1990s which has benefited from extensive foreign investment. This has attracted numerous call centers in recent years. Santo Domingo not only has an excellent telecommunications infrastructure but also a sizeable bilingual population that speaks English.

The city's economic growth can be witnessed in the extensive vertical growth experienced across many of its neighborhoods. The construction boom is reflected in the many high density residential towers
column2: shopping malls
column3: elevated highways
column4: the metro expansion and overall increase in commercial activity.

Santo Domingo has an underground and elevated rapid transit metro system. It is the most extensive metro in the Caribbean and Central American region by total length and number of stations. The Santo Domingo Metro is part of a major "National Master Plan" to improve transportation in the city as well as the rest of the nation.  The first line was planned to relieve traffic congestion in the Máximo Gómez and Hermanas Mirabal Avenue. The second line
column2: which opened in April 2013
column3: is meant to relieve the congestion along the Duarte-Kennedy-Centenario Corridor in the city from west to east. As of August 2013
column4: the metro consists of these two lines. Four more lines are planned to be constructed in the near future
column5: for a total of six. Before the opening of the second line
column8: 515 passengers rode the Santo Domingo Metro in 2012. According to government figures more than 300
column9: 000 people ride the 31 kilometer system on a daily basis.In 2018 a 5 kilometer Santo Domingo cable car (teleferico) was opened to the public with the purpose to provide service to the poorest areas to the east and north of the metropolitan area and serve as a feeder for the metro. The cable car is used by more than 12
